001package com.randomnoun.common;
002
003/* (c) 2013 randomnoun. All Rights Reserved. This work is licensed under a
004 * BSD Simplified License. (http://www.randomnoun.com/bsd-simplified.html)
005 */
006import java.io.FileReader;
007import java.io.IOException;
008import java.io.InputStream;
009import java.io.InputStreamReader;
010import java.io.LineNumberReader;
011import java.io.Reader;
012import java.text.ParseException;
013import java.util.ArrayList;
014import java.util.Iterator;
015import java.util.List;
016import java.util.Map;
017import java.util.Map.Entry;
018import java.util.Properties;
019import java.util.StringTokenizer;
020
021import org.apache.log4j.Logger;
022
023/**
024 * The PropertyParser class parses a property definition text file into
025 * a Properties object.
026 *
027 * <p>This parser differs from the standard Properties parser in that
028 * sections can be marked off for particular regions (e.g. properties
029 * that only take effect in development, or when run on certain machines).
030 * The current region
031 * is specified by the <code>com.randomnoun.common.mode</code> system property
032 * set on the VM commandline. If this system property is not set,
033 * the region defaults to the value "<code>localhost-dev-unknown</code>".
034 * An alternate constructor exists if you
035 * wish to specify the region manually.
036 *
037 * <p>Environments are specified in '<i>machine-release-subsystem</i>'
038 * format, with each segment set as follows:
039 * <ul>
040 * <li>machine - the hostname of the system (in lowercase)
041 * <li>release - the development phase of the system (either set to <code>dev</code>,
042 *   <code>xpt</code>, <code>prd</code> for development, acceptance or production
043 * <li>subsystem - the subsystem that this VM represents. 
044 * </ul>
045 *
046 * <p>Properties are specified in the standard "propertyName=propertyValue" method.
047 * Whitespace is removed from either side of the '=' character. New-lines
048 * can be specified in the property value by using the escape sequence '\n'.
049 * Lines can be continued over a single line by placing the character '\' at
050 * at the end of the line to be continued; e.g.
051 *
052 * <pre style="code">
053 *   property1=value1
054 *   property2=this is a very long value for property2, which spans \
055 *             over a single line.
056 * </pre>
057 *
058 * <p>Properties that are specific to a particular region should be surrounded
059 * by the lines "STARTENVIRONMENT environmentMask" and "ENDENVIRONMENT environmentMask".
060 * Individual properties can be defined for a region by prefixing the line
061 * with "ENV environmentMask"; e.g.
062 *
063 * <pre style="code">
064 *   property1=all regions
065 *
066 *   STARTENVIRONMENT *-xpt-*
067 *     property2=this property only set in acceptance region
068 *     property3=same for this property
069 *   ENDENVIRONMENT
070 *
071 *   STARTENVIRONMENT dtp11523-dev-*
072 *     property2=these properties only set in the development region
073 *     property3=running on the host dtp11523
074 *   ENDENVIRONMENT
075 *
076 *   ENV *-prd-* property4=this property only visible in production
077 * </pre>
078 *
079 * <p>As shown above, the '<code>*</code>' character can be used to specify a property
080 * across multiple regions. The keywords 'STARTENVIRONMENT', 'ENDENVIRONMENT' and
081 * 'ENV' are case-insensitive
082 * 
083 * <p>You can now also specify environments based on the values of previously-defined
084 * properties; this allows a simple <code>#ifdef</code> style facility. There are 
085 * two types of syntax, which use regex matching or simple string matching; e.g.
086 * 
087 * <pre style="code">
088 *   enable.fileAct=true
089 *   compound.property=123-456-789
090 * 
091 *   STARTENVIRONMENT enable.fileAct = true
092 *     # these properties are only set when enable.fileAct is set to true
093 *   ENDENVIRONMENT
094 *   STARTENVIRONMENT compound.property =~ *-789
095 *     # these properties are only set when compound.property ends with -789
096 *   ENDENVIRONMENT
097 * </pre>
098 * 
099 * <p>Property files can contain any number of blank lines, or comments (lines
100 * starting with the '#' character), which will be ignored by the parser.
101 *
102 * <p>Any occurences of the string "<code>\n</code>" in a property value will be
103 * replaced by a newline character.
104 *
105 * <p>A property make also contain a List, rather than a string, by including the
106 * index of the list item in square brackets in the property key; e.g.
107 *
108 * <pre style="code">
109 *   listname[1]=first element
110 *   listname[3]=third element
111 * </pre>
112 *
113 * <p>This implementation returns an ArrayList of Strings for these types of declarations.
114 * Undeclared array elements that appear before the last index will return null.
115 *
116 * <p>If you want to create a list, but the index of the elements is unknown (they are 
117 * dependant on other properties, for example), then you can use a "*" to denote the
118 * next available list index, or leave it empty to denote the last used list index; e.g.
119 * 
120 * <pre style="code">
121 * testList[0].a=a-value 0
122 * testList[0].b=b-value 0
123 * testList[0].c=a-value 0
124 *  
125 * testList[1].a=a-value 1
126 * testList[1].b=b-value 1
127 * testList[1].c=a-value 1
128 *  
129 * testList[*].a=a-value 2
130 * testList[].b=b-value 2
131 * testList[].c=a-value 2
132 * </pre>
133 * 
134 * will generate a three-element list, each of which contains a map with three key/value pairs.
135 *
136 * <p>Properties that appear multiple times will take the value of the last-specified
137 * value.
138 *
139 *
140 * @author  knoxg
141 * 
142 */
143public class PropertyParser {
144
145    /** Logger instance for this class */
146    public static final Logger logger = Logger.getLogger(PropertyParser.class.getName());
147
148    /** display each token as it is read */
149    static private final boolean verbose = false;
150
151    /** file to parse */
152    private LineNumberReader lineReader;
153
154    /** line to parse */
155    private StringTokenizer thisline;
156
157    /** environment processing enabled */
158    private boolean inEnvironment = false;
159
160    /** currently within correct environment */
161    private boolean correctEnvironment = true;
162
163    /** current environment string */
164    private String environmentID = "";
165
166    /** the properties object we will populate from this InputStream */
167    private Properties properties = null;
168
169    /**
170     * Create a new Parser object. Note that parsing does not begin until the
171     * Parse method is called on this object.
172     *
173     * @param reader        The source of the site definition text.
174     * @param environmentID     The environment ID in which to parse this text.
175     */
176    public PropertyParser(Reader reader, String environmentID) {
177        lineReader = new LineNumberReader(reader);
178        this.environmentID = environmentID;
179    }
180
181    /**
182     * Create a new Parser object. Note that parsing does not begin until the
183     * Parse method is called on this object. Assumes a DEV environment
184     *
185     * @param reader The source of the site definition text.
186     */
187    public PropertyParser(Reader reader) {
188        this(reader, System.getProperty("com.randomnoun.common.mode", "localhost-dev-unknown"));
189    }
190
191    /**
192     * Generates a Properties object from the input stream.
193     *
194     * @return A valid Properties object.
195     *
196     * @throws IOException
197     * @throws ParseException
198     */
199    public Properties parse()
200        throws ParseException, IOException {
201        String line = ""; // current line
202        String token = ""; // current token
203
204        // ensure that all class fields have been reset
205        properties = new Properties();
206
207        line = lineReader.readLine();
208
209        while (line != null) {
210            line = line.trim();
211
212            // line-continuation (a line ending with '\' is appended with the next)
213            // could prove hazardous if we get a \ on the last line
214            while (line != null && line.endsWith("\\")) {
215                line = line.substring(0, line.length() - 1);
216
217                try {
218                    line = line + lineReader.readLine().trim();
219                } catch (NullPointerException npe) {
220                    // end of file reached; ignore
221                }
222            }
223
224            // true = don't return delimiters
225            thisline = new StringTokenizer(line, " =\t\n\r", true);
226
227            if (thisline.hasMoreTokens()) {
228                token = parseToken("keyword");
229
230                // are we in the correct environment ?
231                if (correctEnvironment || token.toLowerCase().equals("endenvironment")) {
232                    parseLine(token);
233                }
234            }
235
236            line = lineReader.readLine();
237        }
238
239        return properties;
240    }
241
242    /**
243     * Parses a single line of the site definition file.
244     *
245     * @param token The token that was at the beginning of this line
246     *
247     * @throws ParseException
248     */
249    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
250        private void parseLine(String token)
251        throws ParseException {
252        String lowerCaseToken;
253        String nextToken = null;
254        String value = null;
255
256        // System.out.println("P " + token + "(" + line + ")");
257        lowerCaseToken = token.toLowerCase();
258
259        if (token.startsWith("#")) {
260            // comment
261            // call the appropriate method depending on the keyword...
262        } else if (lowerCaseToken.equals("startenvironment")) {
263            parseStartEnvironment();
264        } else if (lowerCaseToken.equals("endenvironment")) {
265            parseEndEnvironment();
266        } else if (lowerCaseToken.equals("env")) {
267            parseEnv();
268                } else if (lowerCaseToken.equals("includeresource")) {
269                        parseIncludeResource();
270        } else {
271            // see if this is a key=value property assignment
272            try {
273                nextToken = parseToken("token");
274            } catch (ParseException pe) {
275                newParseException("Unknown keyword '" + token + "', '=' expected");
276            }
277
278            if (nextToken.equals("=")) {
279                // must be in a key=value assignment
280                value = null;
281
282                try {
283                    value = parseTokenToEOL("property value");
284                } catch (ParseException pe) {
285                }
286
287                if (value == null) {
288                    value = "";
289                }
290
291                // check if this is an array element    
292                int lb = token.indexOf('[');
293                int rb = token.indexOf(']');
294                
295
296                if (lb != -1 || rb != -1) {
297                    if (lb == -1 || rb == -1) {
298                        newParseException("Invalid list property key '" + token + "'");
299                    }
300                    List<Object> list = null;
301                    String keyPart = token.substring(0, lb);
302                    String listPart = token.substring(lb);
303                    try {
304                        list = (List<Object>) properties.get(keyPart);
305                    } catch (ClassCastException cce) {
306                        newParseException("Cannot create list '" + token + "', this property already exists");
307                    }
308                    if (list == null) {
309                        list = new ArrayList<Object>();
310                        properties.put(keyPart, list);
311                    }
312                    // if list index is "*" then create a new list index; if it's "-", then use the last index
313                    String index = token.substring(lb+1, rb);
314                    if (index.equals("*")) {
315                        index = String.valueOf(list.size()); // 0-based list, so next index is set to the size
316                        listPart = "[" + index + "]" + listPart.substring(listPart.indexOf("]")+1);
317                    } else if (index.equals("")) {
318                        index = String.valueOf(list.size()-1);
319                                                listPart = "[" + index + "]" + listPart.substring(listPart.indexOf("]")+1);
320                    }
321                    
322                    Struct.setValue(list, listPart, value, true, true, true);
323                } else {
324                    // no index supplied, just set the property 
325                    properties.setProperty(token, value);
326                }
327            } else {
328                newParseException("Unknown token '" + nextToken + "', '=' expected");
329            }
330        }
331    }
332
333    /**
334     * Creates and throws a new parse exception, which includes the current parse
335     * position within the Reader.
336     *
337     * @param s The additional text to be included in this exception
338     *
339     * @throws ParseException The parse exception requested
340     */
341    private void newParseException(String s)
342        throws ParseException {
343        throw new ParseException("line " + lineReader.getLineNumber() + ": " + s, 0);
344    }
345
346    /**
347     * Returns the next token.
348     *
349     * @param what The type of token we are expecting. This string is only used
350     *   in any parseExceptions which are thrown.
351     *
352     * @return The next token on the line.
353     *
354     * @throws ParseException A parsing exception has occurred.
355     */
356    private String parseToken(String what)
357        throws ParseException {
358        String result = null;
359
360        // keep grabbing tokens, until we hit something that isn't considered whitespace
361        while (result == null || result.equals(" ") || result.equals("\r") || result.equals("\n") || result.equals("\t")) {
362            if (!thisline.hasMoreTokens()) {
363                newParseException("Expecting " + what);
364            }
365
366            result = thisline.nextToken(" =\t\n\r");
367        }
368
369        // convert \n's to newlines.
370        result = result.replaceAll("\\\\n", "\n");
371
372        if (verbose) {
373            logger.debug("parsed token: '" + result + "'");
374        }
375
376        return result;
377    }
378
379    /**
380     * Grabs every token until the end of line, and returns it as a string. If the
381     * debugging variable 'verbose' is set to true, then each token is sent
382     * to System.out as it is read. Enclosing single or double-quotes are removed.
383     *
384     * @param what The type of token we are expecting. This text is used
385     *   in any parseExceptions which are thrown.
386     *
387     * @return The remaining text.
388     *
389     * @throws ParseException
390     */
391    private String parseTokenToEOL(String what)
392        throws ParseException {
393        String token;
394
395        if (!thisline.hasMoreTokens()) {
396            newParseException("Expecting " + what);
397        }
398
399        token = thisline.nextToken("\n").trim();
400        token = token.replaceAll("\\\\n", "\n");
401
402        if (verbose) {
403            System.out.println("parsed token: " + token);
404        }
405
406        return token;
407    }
408
409    /**
410     * Processes an ENV rule
411     *
412     * @throws ParseException
413     */
414    private void parseEnv()
415        throws ParseException {
416        String selectedenvironmentID;
417        String token;
418
419        selectedenvironmentID = parseToken("Environment ID");
420
421        // @TODO this should really use the same rules as parseStartEnvironment
422        if (selectedenvironmentID.equals(environmentID)) {
423            token = parseToken("keyword").toLowerCase();
424            parseLine(token);
425        }
426    }
427
428        private void parseIncludeResource() throws ParseException {
429                // include another properties file in here. This has a very
430                // good chance of creating a infinite loop if one property file
431                // includes another one, which in turn includes the first one. 
432                // - this will manifest itself in some kind of OutOfMemoryException
433                // or a StackOverflowException
434                
435                String resourceName = parseTokenToEOL("resource name");
436                logger.debug("Including property resource '" + resourceName + "'");
437
438                // load properties from classpath (in .EAR)
439                InputStream inputStream = PropertyParser.class.getClassLoader().getResourceAsStream(resourceName);
440                if (inputStream==null) {
441                        throw new ParseException("Could not find included resource '" + resourceName + "'", 0);
442                }
443                PropertyParser propertyParser = new PropertyParser(new InputStreamReader(inputStream), environmentID);
444                Properties includedProperties = new Properties();
445                try {
446                        includedProperties = propertyParser.parse();
447                } catch (Exception e) {
448                        throw (ParseException) new ParseException("Could not load included resource '" +
449                                resourceName + "'", 0).initCause(e);
450                }
451                
452                // should merge lists/maps, rather than replacing them.
453                // (maybe this should be configurable ?)
454                // @TODO code below only merges lists
455                for (Iterator<Entry<Object, Object>> i = includedProperties.entrySet().iterator(); i.hasNext(); ) {
456                        Map.Entry<Object, Object> entry = i.next();
457                        if (entry.getValue() instanceof List) {
458                                Object existingObj = properties.get(entry.getKey());
459                                if (existingObj==null || !(existingObj instanceof List)) {
460                                        properties.put(entry.getKey(), entry.getValue());
461                                } else {
462                                        @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
463                                        List<Object> existingList = (List<Object>) existingObj;
464                                        @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
465                                        List<Object> listValue = (List<Object>) entry.getValue();
466                                        for (int j=0; j<listValue.size(); j++) {
467                                                if (listValue.get(j)!=null) {
468                                                        Struct.setListElement(existingList, j, listValue.get(j));
469                                                }
470                                        }
471                                }
472                        } else {
473                                properties.put(entry.getKey(), entry.getValue());
474                        }
475                }
476                // properties.putAll(includedProperties);
477        }
478
479    /** Begins per-environment parsing rules.
480     *  @throws ParseException
481     */
482    private void parseStartEnvironment()
483        throws ParseException {
484        if (inEnvironment) {
485            newParseException("attempted to nest environment areas");
486        }
487        String propertyName = "environmentId";
488        String propertyMatch = null;
489        String propertyValue = null;
490        String envSpec = parseTokenToEOL("Environment specification");
491        if (envSpec.indexOf("=~")!=-1) {
492                propertyName = envSpec.substring(0, envSpec.indexOf("=~")).trim();
493                propertyMatch = envSpec.substring(envSpec.indexOf("=~")+2).trim();
494                        propertyMatch = propertyMatch.replaceAll("\\*", ".*");
495                propertyValue = propertyName.equals("environmentId") ? environmentID : properties.getProperty(propertyName);
496                if (propertyValue==null) { propertyValue = ""; }
497                        correctEnvironment = propertyValue.matches(propertyMatch);      
498        } else if (envSpec.indexOf("=")!=-1) {
499                        propertyName = envSpec.substring(0, envSpec.indexOf("=")).trim();
500                        propertyMatch = envSpec.substring(envSpec.indexOf("=")+1).trim();
501                        propertyValue = propertyName.equals("environmentId") ? environmentID : properties.getProperty(propertyName);
502                        if (propertyValue==null) { propertyValue = ""; }
503                        correctEnvironment = propertyValue.equals(propertyMatch);       
504        } else {
505                // not on 'xxx=xxx' form, default to old behaviour (match on envId)
506                        propertyMatch = envSpec.replaceAll("\\*", ".*");
507                        correctEnvironment = environmentID.toLowerCase().matches(propertyMatch.toLowerCase());
508        }
509        
510        // test for "property=value" style environments
511        //selectedenvironmentID = selectedenvironmentID.replaceAll("\\*", ".*");
512        //correctEnvironment = environmentID.matches(selectedenvironmentID);
513        inEnvironment = true;
514    }
515
516    /**
517     * Completes per-environment parsing rules.
518     *
519     * @throws ParseException
520     */
521    private void parseEndEnvironment()
522        throws ParseException {
523        if (!inEnvironment) {
524            newParseException("'endenvironment' without matching 'startenvironment'");
525        }
526
527        inEnvironment = false;
528        correctEnvironment = true;
529    }
530
531    /**
532     * Returns a subset of a Properties object. The subset is determined by only
533     * returning those key/value pairs whose keys begin with a set prefix. e.g.
534     * if 'a' contains the properties
535     *
536     * <pre>
537     *   customer.1.name=fish
538     *   customer.1.description=Patagonian toothfish
539     *   customer.2.name=hunter
540     *   customer.2.description=Patagonian toothfish hunter
541     *   customer.11.name=spear
542     *   customer.11.description=Patagonian toothfish hunter's spear
543     * </pre>
544     *
545     * <p>then calling <code>restrict(a, "customer.1", false)</code> will return:
546     *
547     * <pre>
548     *   customer.1.name=fish
549     *   customer.1.description=Patagonian toothfish
550     * </pre>
551     *
552     * <p>setting the 'removePrefix' to true will remove the initial prefix from
553     * the returned property list; <code>restrict(a, "customer.1", true)</code> in
554     * this case will then return:
555     *
556     * <pre>
557     *   name=fish
558     *   description=Patagonian toothfish
559     * </pre>
560     *
561     * <p>Note that the prefix passed in to this method has no trailing period,
562     * but each property must contain that period (to prevent <code>customer.11</code>
563     * from being returned in the example above).
564     *
565     * <p>If 'properties' is set to null, then this method will return null.
566     * If 'prefix' is set to null, then this method will return the entire property list.
567     *
568     * @param properties The initial property list that we wish to restrict
569     * @param prefix     The prefix used to restrict the property list
570     * @param removePrefix  If set to true, the result keys will be stripped of the initial prefix text
571     *
572     * @return A restricted property list.
573     */
574    public static Map<? extends Object, ? extends Object> restrict(Map<Object, Object> properties, String prefix, boolean removePrefix) {
575        if (properties == null) {
576            return null;
577        }
578
579        if (prefix == null) {
580            return properties;
581        }
582
583        Properties result = new Properties();
584
585        // this could possibly break existing, yet weird code
586        // if (!prefix.endsWith(".")) { prefix = prefix + "."; };
587        prefix = prefix + ".";
588        
589        Map.Entry<Object, Object> entry;
590
591        for (Iterator<Entry<Object, Object>> i = properties.entrySet().iterator(); i.hasNext();) {
592            entry = i.next();
593
594            String key = (String) entry.getKey();
595
596            if (key.startsWith(prefix)) {
597                if (removePrefix) {
598                    key = key.substring(prefix.length());
599                }
600
601                result.put(key, entry.getValue());
602            }
603        }
604
605        return result;
606    }
607
608    /**
609     * Method used to test the parser from the command line. The file to parse is
610     * specified on the command line; if missing, then it uses 'test.properties'
611     * as the default.
612     *
613     * @param args
614     *
615     * @throws IOException
616     * @throws ParseException
617     */
618    public static void main(String[] args)
619        throws IOException, ParseException {
620        String filename = "test.properties";
621        PropertyParser propertyParser;
622
623        if (args.length != 1) {
624            System.out.println("Reading from '" + filename + "' by default...");
625        } else {
626            filename = args[0];
627        }
628
629        try {
630            propertyParser = new PropertyParser(new FileReader(filename));
631            propertyParser.parse();
632            System.out.println("Parse OK");
633        } catch (ParseException pe) {
634            System.out.println("Caught ParseException: " + pe);
635            pe.printStackTrace();
636        }
637    }
638}
